name: STarT Back Tool
description: 9-question prognostic tool for low back pain, stratifying patients into risk groups for persistent disabling pain
patientFriendlyDescription: Help us understand your back pain and find the best way to help you recover

questions.label: Leg Pain
questions.description: Has your back pain spread down your leg(s) at any time in the last 2 weeks?

questions.label: Shoulder or Neck Pain
questions.description: Have you had pain in your shoulder or neck at any time in the last 2 weeks?

questions.label: Walking Difficulties
questions.description: Have you only been able to walk short distances because of your back pain?

questions.label: Dressing Difficulties
questions.description: In the last 2 weeks, have you dressed more slowly than usual because of back pain?

questions.label: Fear of Physical Activity
questions.description: Do you feel it's not safe for someone with your condition to be physically active?

questions.label: Worrying Thoughts
questions.description: Have worrying thoughts been going through your mind a lot of the time?

questions.label: Negative Thoughts About Recovery
questions.description: Do you feel that your back pain is terrible and will never get better?

questions.label: Reduced Enjoyment
questions.description: In general, have you not enjoyed the things you used to enjoy?

questions.label: Pain Bothersomeness
questions.description: Overall, how bothersome has your back pain been in the last 2 weeks?

riskCategories.name: Low Risk
riskCategories.description: Low risk of persistent disabling low back pain - Good prognosis with minimal intervention

riskCategories.name: Medium Risk
riskCategories.description: Medium risk of persistent disabling low back pain - May benefit from targeted physiotherapy

riskCategories.name: High Risk
riskCategories.description: High risk of persistent disabling low back pain - Requires psychologically-informed intervention

metadata.clinicalUse: Risk stratification for low back pain to guide treatment decisions and predict prognosis for persistent disabling pain
